@Walker Reynolds 
1. Production data, raw material consumption
2. Jobs/production orders programmed

Author: gopinathps
Content:
> Questions of the day:

> 1. What data exists on the plant floor that most organizations would benefit from having it available for the ERP?
> 
> 2. What data exists in the ERP that most organizations would benefit from having it available on the plant floor?
> 
> 3. What is the biggest challenge in connecting or merging OT (the plant floor) with IT (business systems like ERP) data?
@Walker Reynolds 

Interesting question, answering from my view point so far,

1. What data exists on the plant floor that most organizations would benefit from having it available for the ERP?

    a. Consumption and Production (101/261 on SAP terms)
    b. Material reservation and issue
    c. FG Warehousing 
    d. Dispatch details (every product) for the delivery order created in ERP
    e. Machine breakdown intimation to create tickets to fix
    f. scrap or rework data
    g. utilities monitoring (energy/steam etc.,) per product
    h. Tool usage data like a bladder or moulds
    i. Quality data, PDI etc.,
    j. Machine availability in case of an ERP integrated scheduler


2. What data exists in the ERP that most organizations would benefit from having it available on the plant floor?

    a. Material Reservation per shift basis
    b. Production Orders, linked to a scheduler
    c. Maintenance orders created to sort out a breakdown at the machine
    d. Dispatch or Delivery orders to be executed based on priority

3. What is the biggest challenge in connecting or merging OT (the plant floor) with IT (business systems like ERP) data?
    
    a. Data contextualization which deals with lots of customization

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
> Anyone: for your larger international clients (US + elsewhere) what ERPs do you typically see used and/or would prefer were used in the 4.0 journey?  I specify international as the ERP would have to support international money transfers, multi-site, that kind of enterprise size.  The top 3-4 that come to mind might be: SAP, Oracle (NetSuite I think), and Microsoft Dynamics, and maybe Infor but not 100% sure on that one.  Any of those you'd favor over another, or another not listed, that could handle that size ERP need well in a 4.0+ fashion?
@John Sullivan 

My preference is two-tier:  Plex + Workday.

Plex is a manufacturing-centric ERP with modules for MES, quality, supply chain, accounting, purchasing, maintenance, etc.  It's quality management and inventory functionality are exceptional.  It's like an ERP where the shop floor functionality was built out first and then finance / HR last.  Usually it's the other way around.  It's weak on HR.  In terms of financials, most corporate finance departments might be used to something more polished.  It has enterprise capabilities like financial consolidation, centralized treasury, multi-entity, international etc.  But, not like the way the traditional finance-centric ERPs would.  But, in terms of plant-level financials, corporate finance types might be pleasantly surprised.  The accounting and purchasing modules are deeply integrated into manufacturing modules.  The manufacturing activities drive financial transactions.  A/P, A/R, and costing are a breeze.  In the end, good accounting software is only as good as the data its fed.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Workday is a very popular HCM and is best-in-class.  It was built by the founders of PeopleSoft after the hostile takeover by Oracle.  In recent years it's expanded into Financials and other more traditional ERP functionality.  It's one of the few big ERPs that is technologically modern (i.e., not software recycled from the 20th century).  It's cloud-native, it uses an object-store rather than conventional relational database, and it has a real integration layer.  Workday has very capable financials functionality and reporting.  Big multinationals use it.  Some use just the HCM and use other solutions for financials like HCM.  The strength is its platform.  It's process-oriented and it's built for integration.

TL;DR:  Workday at HQ.  Plex at the plants.  Workday handles corporate-level financial consolidation and planning.  Workday handles all HR.  Plex handles everything else

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
If you have really intense finance functionality requirements, SAP is the most capable.  Their whole ecosystem is, well, let's say complicated.  They're perfectly capable and are available in every corner of the world.  I wouldn't necessarily endorse them for running your whole business end-to-end.

Outside of supply chain, I'm not really a fan of Oracle.  Netsuite, an Oracle acquisition, is good solution for vanilla ERP workloads (e.g., finance, hr).  I wouldn't say that the manufacturing functionality is exceptionally strong.  They have a similarly complicated legacy as SAP, but also with a very certain way of doing business.  You have to "jive" with Oracle for it to work.

Author: davem8428
Content: Some thoughts on Zack‚Äôs question, not any input for method/guide but a nod to the value in learning from fabulous failure! One of the (many) early lessons of this ERP disaster: draw clear and hard lines of control and process ownership between modules and systems, and make sure those lines map to what is done on the shop floor. In this bad example, SAP ERP with WM integrated to a WMS+ASRS and a MES: all systems have container level inventory with multiple level storage units and transport carriers, all systems to a degree can change and move inventory around and all systems are available on the factory floor in different forms (mobiles, desktops etc). The intended design defined which steps to be done in which systems and sequence following logical flow from receipt through sampling, put away, picking to staging and production but quickly due to frustration and system errors then operators navigated to instead using the most convenient and accessible tool not necessarily the intended one. The number of unexpected transactions quickly snowballed into several 100‚Äôs of failed interface messages for inventory movement alone daily, each error resulting in an item that could not be used at all, or was in the wrong state for the physical activity giving at best strange behaviour or at worst a total hard stop to operations. The triage team multiplied accordingly until all 3 system vendors and internal client departments had people struggling to keep up with 1000‚Äôs of support tickets building up after just a few days post go-live. So, as an input to method from this failure: then start with as-is process flow, walk the shop floor and talk to people to understand the business processes and their constraints then identify what exactly they need, and what they don‚Äôt and how to make it as easy as possible for them by ensuring the footprint of systems do not overlap. Do this a long time before you start running integration workshops with IF experts!

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Openness is much more opaque in the ERP world.  In terms of database and API connectivity, that's generally not a problem.  Direct vendor lock-in is not really a problem as the cost of switching is enough of a deterrent.  In terms of changing source code or functionality, it's complicated.  There is much more breadth and depth of functionality.  There is somewhat of a tradeoff, at least in the long-run, between openness and resiliency.  Ignition and FS are platforms where those deploying largely build their own business processes and functionality.  The ERP world is different in that functionality deployed typically will be both built and tailored.  That is, sometimes the business processes will be designed around the ERP and sometimes it's the business process "designing" the ERP.  This will govern how "open" the platform is perceived.

Personally, I like multi-tenant SaaS platforms for ERP.  I believe that there is more innovation in platforms where all deployments are running on the same code base and version.  It's easier to enhance and support.  The community also tends to be more engaged and collaborative.  Nothing harms the long-term value of an ERP and the agility of company than an overly-customized deployment.  This is generally the problem with many on-prem and private cloud solutions.  They can become impossible to lifecycle.  Most organizations struggle enough with implementation and are not equipped handle a brownfield deployment.

Cloud ERP has its tradeoffs.  One must put a lot of faith in their partner(s).  But, over the long-run, there tends to be more functionality available that can be adopted practically and a more robust ecosystem driving it.  This is why I like Plex and Workday.  They're a stretch for some SMB, but they can deliver massive value if they're fully embraced.

Here's my response on a previous ERP question:

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Yes, but primarily from a rip-and-replace perspective.  What I've encountered might be a function of GP itself, those (ab)using it, or both.  Take my input with a grain-of-salt.

All migrations have been done with SQL.  Most integrations I've observed were through SQL and some with COM.  GP, at least on-prem, has a fairly weak and inconsistently-implemented data model.  I've seen some, no joke, AS/400 migrations and integrations go smoother.  For some reason, GP really attracts a lot of database abuse.  Think hijacked columns, redundant tables, poor normalization, etc.  It appears the community tends to modify the schema to customize canned reports or functionality rather than develop/extend their own.  It's fragile.

For these reasons, I would advise proceeding with caution integrating with the database.  Some ERP apps have special transaction tables or stored procedures for integration.  They usually have some sort of validation and enforce business logic like an API would.  By comparison, GP appears to be a lot less formal about this.  It's not that SQL can't work.  Be cognizant of the data model and logic.  The integration will have to respect this.  A "blind" insert statement with enough assumptions can create problems down the road.

If it's on-prem, I would look into the .NET SDK or third-party GP integrations.  There is a whole industry of GP integration products and services.  You will be hard-pressed to find something that will expose GP as an MQTT client.  More likely, there will be HTTP/S or SOAP interfaces.  The UNS can be setup to invoke these.

I can't speak to the M365 cloud version.  I don't know if they performed a lift-and-shift (i.e., private cloud) or they rebuilt it as multi-tenant.  If it's multi-tenant, there will be less uncertainty about the database and more opportunities for integration.  Are there documented APIs?  Check out if there are any hooks into MS Flows or another integration product in the M365 platform.

In a cnc context where reliability of the physical control system is priority #1, it makes sense that it's preferable to store programs locally, esp if your goal is to process hundreds of blocks per second at 100% reliability. You could also use dprint but who wants to do that? 

As far as it not being appropriate for all environments, make to print and job shops specifically, I've done a lot of thinking about this and I disagree. If your nc program is coming out of a computer, there is absolutely no reason that the post can't be modified to pass these params through automagically, and the operator never even needs to fuss with it (frictionless should be the goal).

Nothing wrong with FTP (besides security, arguably, but that wouldn't be improved by using native protocols anyways) as long as you automate the file transfer and implement an automated verification process.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
My response was based on two topics @BenG asked.  The first was on order info as it relates to various applications (e.g., MES, PDM/PLM).  The second was on the topic of distributing g-code through the UNS.

ERP topics can be tough to discuss because the approaches of product realization and commercialization can vary so much by organization.  The fact that there exist ERPs with hundreds of options to support order management exemplifies this.  My point was that a lot of business processes can be driven independent of customer orders.  For example, a BOM might feed into different parts for multiple customer orders.  The engineering of said BOM might be governed more by internal requirements than customer requirements.  As a result, it may not be optimal to explicitly model by customer order in the way that say a contract manufacturer or a job shop would.

As for distributing g-code, leveraging UNS is an interesting concept.  It's all theoretically possible and I don't dispute the potential.  When I think about the major products in this space (e.g., CAM, DNC, CNC), they're tied together with explicit point-to-point connections and, often, dedicated interfaces.  Typically, but not definitively, there aren't any other producers or consumers of this data.  This is not an axiom to live by, but a mere practical observation.  Rather than engineering conversions from file transfer protocols into a UNS and back out for each machine type, it might be more practical to leverage a traditional DNC infrastructure for program transfer but expose its meta data to other application nodes via a UNS.  For example, do other nodes need raw g-code or do they need to do know information about it (e.g., Part No, Rev, Program Name)?

This could be an example, as Walker has put it, where discrete connections are not totally replaced but reduced.  Innovating with industrial tech frequently requires "hybrid" approaches of old and new.

Author: pt.ox
Content: That's exactly what I'm saying, you can already do this really easily. For example, job is put into ERP. Change is made in CAM. Upon posting, CAM calls for part rev number, job number, submits new program rev number to ERP. When the pmc loads the program, all these are also inputted into macro vars on the control which are then picked up and submitted back to the ERP so we know that what we want running is in fact running. If you centralize the data there you also have the benefit of being able to cross reference tooling libraries twice or three times (not sure what scale you're talking about, but i'm going to assume for the purposes of this example that the tools are being put into the machine by humans)

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Not these two together, no.  I've seen Netsuite deployed most often for services and supply chain oriented orgs.  

While Netsuite runs on an Oracle database, it's not really a traditional Oracle product like Oracle ERP or JD Edwards.  They were acquired by Oracle in 2016.  Netsuite is a multi-tenant cloud ERP.  That is, the application code base and its underlying database are shared by all of its customers.  This means you cannot modify the database schema or make direct writes.  Instead, everything will go through APIs.  Netsuite exposes itself with REST or SOAP interfaces.  They do have integration libraries that can be embedded into a program, but for Ignition, API calls will probably the best route.

Find out what your client is currently doing with Netsuite (e.g., CRM, Order Management, Supply Chain Management, Accounting).  Next, find out what they're currently manually logging in the system.  Are they updating orders, inventory, cost, shipments, etc?  Identify what are the most common transactions and what are most laborious.  Finally, you'll want someone at the client familiar with Netsuite APIs.  Ideally, they should be able to replicate what a business process owner (e.g., order management) does with the Netsuite GUI over an API.  If they don't, that's okay.  You can do this work for them and partner up with someone.  At the very least, you'll need someone internally that owns the business processes and can validate the integrations are working.

If the client does not have the capability to support this kind of thing, I'd suggest getting their Netsuite implementation partner involved.  They'll be more technically aclimated with what the client has.  If they don't have a good relationship with them or they don't have any experience working with a system integrator, reach out to Netsuite for a partner who has.

Content: In one of the Videos Walker speaks about the significance of B2MML in ERP integration, my question is how is this related to the UNS for integration to ERP?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I'm not sure what video you're referencing.  I'll chime in on the topic in general.

B2MML is an XML representation of ISA95.  Some ERPs expose their master data model or parts of it as B2MML.  B2MML can be used to exchange data in standardized way between ERP, SCM, MES, etc.  It can also be used for archival and traceability in some regulated industries.

In practice, B2MML is sort of like OPC-UA information models.  The adoption of it is not broad or consistent.  B2MML-based integrations invariably require customization.  As a result, it's much more common to leverage the native data representation and interfaces in applications for integration.  Ask any product manager or implementer of these apps and they'll have all sorts of thoughts on it.  Due to the varied adherence to standards and implementations of MES itself, plug-n-play in the MES world is a challenge.  

With that said, if available, B2MML can function as a familiar schema to work with.  It can take time learning the native interfaces.  And sometimes, underlying data models will have subtle differences based on implementation or version.  Without knowledge of the differences, it can be a challenge working with native interfaces.  It might require using a specific API or specific version of an API to get to the data.

B2MML is worth being familiar with as a "conduit" into some ERPs.  Understanding how to move records (e.g., BOMs, routings, orders, assets, workcenters) through this conduit is necessary to create of the business structure and state that is the UNS.  Presently, most ERPs will not have native MQTT SpB interface.  ERP integration is not simply a matter of pointing it to a broker.  Knowledge of where data resides and how to get it is required.  Regardless of the interface and format (e.g., B2MML, BAPI/RFC, custom web service, SQL sproc), one should be prepared to adapt these into the UNS.  Everything from tools (e.g., Sepasoft, HighByte) to custom scripts can help solve this problem.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
For example, a manufacturer may have stood up a specific MES for their industry.  The solution or its ecosystem may have been built around exchanging data with B2MML.  Taking this into consideration, the ERP may have been stood up with an integration module that supports B2MML.  It might be a preferred integration for the MES or implementation partners.  This makes the manufacturer is essentially a B2MML shop.  Even if there are other interfaces available, most integration knowledge will be B2MML centric.

So, if the UNS needs a list of BOMs or orders for other applications to consume, understanding how B2MML exposes this data becomes relevant.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It's just my opinion, but I would not try to integrate B2MML messages into the UNS. my reasons are as follows:
- B2MML (or IEC62264 part 4) is a transaction message. It is almost always request/response, and while it is entirely possible to handle request/response through asynchonous publish and subscribe, it creates a whole bunch of headaches.
- B2MML messages often do not refer to the current state. An Operations Response message my be sent for the previous order for example, so the B2MML message is often inconsistent with the current state of equipment.
- the messages themselves are complex and not completely hierarchical, so you have to put the whole payload into one message, which brings it back to the first point.

"Event Driven" architectures should not be seen as a silver bullet to solve every problem. While they do solve a bunch of specific problems, they also create a bunch of their own problems. Integration between MES and ERP is mostly transactional, and sometimes event driven.

What I typically do is use the event from PubSub to trigger a synchronous transaction. For example, lets say we need to update the ERP when an order starts on a machine. The MES would subscribe to the UNS to detect when the order state on the machine has changed. This would trigger a synchronous transaction between the ERP and the MES.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I agree with all of this.  B2MML has no place in the "backbone" of IIoT.  Your critique perhaps even illustrates why B2MML has not worked well as a point-to-point integration.

I was referring to B2MML in a brownfield context.  I should have been more clear in saying that one might need to adapt B2MML nodes into the UNS.  This doesn't mean that the UNS will have B2MML connections and payloads, but that it will have connections (e.g., MQTT) and payloads (e.g., SpB + JSON) derived from B2MML.

This is similar to the way one would approach a PLC with a native interface such as EtherNet/IP.  The UNS would not poll a PLC for CIP messages, but rather a gateway would.  A gateway would extract the relevant contents of the CIP messages and publish them to the UNS in a way that meets the requirements (e.g., report by exception, edge driven).

The structure and content of a UNS is often derived from ISA95 in some form.  B2MML, based on ISA95 as well as supported by some ERP and MES apps, can serve as an adapted "brownfield" connection.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Here is one for the most curious guy on the planet. üôÇ

Most people try to relate an ERP with an app or a technical system, but unfortunately, it's much more than that. The business logic is so nested that it's almost a dark tunnel with no end in sight that even people with over 200 implementations and 20+ years of experience struggle to understand. 

I have not met a single person who would understand more than 20-30% of the ERP systems. 

Now, this experience would be similar to an instance of an interview with an economist who set the policies for 60 years. They asked if he had a complete grasp of the economy and his answer was that he had no clue how the economy truly works. He could probably explain the implications of a few policies. 

I remember you comparing manufacturing with Airline and if Mainframe systems are still used. The largest ERP (or a transactional system) is not the ERP system you use. It's not as complex. The largest ERP system in my mind is Sabre, which is used by most airlines as a booking system that most airline brokers and marketplaces use. A lot of companies tried to replace that system, but every time they tried, they have always failed. And as far as my understanding goes, I don't see a possibility of it being replaced in the next 20 years. The last project was done by HP called JetStream, which I believe was still a failed attempt. By the way, Sabre is just an operational system. It's not even a financial system. The financial systems tend to be far more complex.

Now the specific story..

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
A company tried to implement an ERP but when they wanted to ingrate with their distributors through EDI, they chose to bypass the business logic layer. The reason why most software OEMs ask you to utilize their API is that irrespective of whether you process the transactions through the UI or through API, or for that matter EDI,  all transactions must go through the same business logic.

Now, when you bypass the API and try to hit the DB directly, you are bypassing the business logic layer, which has been tested by thousands of companies millions of times and you are overriding the core business logic. Your assumption is going to be that by looking at a bunch of fields, you can probably forecast the implications that your changes would have on the state of the entire system. But now go back to my original point that most people understand 20-30% of the ERP systems. So while you might feel that you have your testing strategy figured out but most likely your changes will break something else, because you don't know what you don't know.

In their case, they hit the DB directly to input the sales order, inv transactions from a distributor, but they forgot that when you enter the line on the sales order, there is massively nested business logic for lot control and how inventory will be put away. In some cases, companies might even have a predictive algorithm to predict the appropriate bin for the product and which lot number the inventory should come out. They built custom logic to mimic the same behavior that you would have from the UI assuming that the logic was going to work. Initially, first, the whole control logic was a mess and it never worked. So then they tried to take out the lot control and then the system started even breaking further. Most products will go to the wrong bins...

A naive sales director was so fascinated by technology because she saw these enterprise reps carrying tabs to the customer meetings. She wished she could do the same. So she created the requirement spec that she wanted to have the accessibility of order history for the past 5 years, so she could show to the customer who she could barely meet once per year during their annual meeting, to show what they ordered in the past 5 years, how their account performance was, and then if there is any problem with a specific sales order, she could discuss the issues and discuss potential remedies.

Now here is the problem with this read-only transaction:

1. pulling 5 years' worth of data is a massive lift from the system performance perspective. You can literally kill the operational system
2. the more data you keep in your ERP system, the slower it gets because of the indexing requirements, etc.
3. tablet is not an appropriate form factor for such a heavy transaction
4. performing such transactions in real-time could slow down everyone else and perhaps may result in database locks etc.

We have seen disasters even when you are going to do point-to-point integration through API as you need to throttle the load etc while integrating. Got a couple of stories there as well where we have seen architectural disasters even through API. but at least, with APIs, you are not fixing electrical circuits with bare hands.

The other things you are better off doing in other systems that are designed for it. If you are updating the state of products and resources in the ERP, that's the right fit. But loading unnecessary operational or plant data may be over bloating your ERP.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's the best example:  Most ERP, themselves, don't even directly read/write to the database in their own apps.  Instead, they'll build a stored procedure and expose it as a datasource.  Even if the business logic is enforced at a database level, the stored procedure will be closely controlled as an official way of accessing data.  

It's critical to control the changes (e.g., schema, aliasing), performance, security, and intent of these.  Without this control, all sorts of technical debt accumulates.  DBAs begin compensating to keep up with misuse by applications, developers begin compensating to keep their apps running, and any change becomes impossible.

When implementation partners or end-users overlook this, it creates all sorts of risk including project failure and operational impacts.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content: While SAP is a great company, it might not have all the solutions that you need for your specific needs. Also, when you use systems from multiple vendors, they are likely not as integrated as from the same vendor. And you will have communication issues because of that. The question always is going to be how much money you have in your pocket,  and what are you trying to accomplish from the architecture. The decisions are typically not as binary as SAP vs non-SAP. They start  with writing all your business processes and design all the solutions containing diff systems and architecture, write down all the risks in each approach (make sure you identify internally owned code and system integrator owned code as part of the analysis as they are typically the riskiest items for your implementation), and finally build a financial model with realistic expectations to figure out which solution is the cheapest and least risky. By the way, this exercise might take 3-6 months, so don't forget to include the costs of that. But at least it will save you a lot of trouble later on once you have signed the multi-year contract with a system or architecture that might not deliver what you were looking for.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
It's kind of interesting how people think of ERP as accounting software. The reality is that even accountants hate them as they have very little understanding of what an ERP system offers for your business. And how businesses are supposed to run. 

The reality is also that when you have lived in a room in your whole life, the only thing you can see up top is the roof. You don't see what's above the roof. The reason why ERP systems are rigid as businesses are supposed to be rigid. There is nothing easy about accounting and law. There is a reason why there are 4-year, if not 8-year degrees certifications for accounting and law so you can learn how to run a business. 

The people who claim that there is nothing rigid about manufacturing have very little understanding of how businesses are supposed to run. The reason why ERP systems feel rigid is that they are designed for inter-departmental workflow, transactional/data integrity, collaboration, and communication with financial control at each step. 

They are not supposed to be biased to serve the needs of just one dept. 

They are supposed to be providing the financial glue that you need to run your business successfully. 

You can use as many systems as you like in your architecture. 

But you need a traffic cop sitting in between that can do the quarterbacking. In most cases, that's your ERP system unless the company is truly screwed up or run by folks who aren't qualified to run, to begin with. On that note, how many people like traffic cops here? NONE right? Exactly, that's probably the reason why no one likes ERP systems. But we need cops to run this world as much as you hate them.

Most ERP vendors offer their MES solutions including SAP, Infor (new acquisition), Epicor, and Plex...

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
There also seems to be a tendency to put everything in the "SAP" bucket. SAP has many different ERP offerings, and they are all not created equal. And they most likely will have different integration capabilities. In fact, the integration capabilities might vary across deployment types and versions. For example, SAP ECC might be the most integrated. But you might not have similar capabilities in its cloud variant SAP S/4 HANA. There are other mid-market products from SAP such as ByDesign and B1. They might not have similar manufacturing capabilities as SAP ECC.  

When you move to products like SAP ECC or SAP S/4 HANA, you pretty much get anything and everything that a global, complex organization would need. The comparable in this space would be Oracle Cloud ERP or MS Dynamics F&O. In all three cases, the capabilities are likely to be similar, and they will be equally rigid as they are designed to run very large, corporat-y, bloated organizations.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
With the right implementation team and if there is not too much customization required, SAP can work well.  For some industry verticals and in some corners of the world, it's sometimes one of the few options.  The unfortunate reality of the SAP ecosystem is that it's among the worst for an inexperienced/uneducated company to navigate.  The only ecosystem with more bad actors taking advantage of this is probably Oracle.  Deep ERP and MES implementations require a "DTMA"-like alignment across the organization.  There must be some pre-requisites.

The issue with lack of success is multifaceted:

Ability to make decisions in a timely manner.

IT managed the project as a typical application deployment.  There was no emphasis on defining and managing the underlying business processes.  If they can't grasp or perform line-of-business functions with reasonable competency, it will be hard for them to create business processes.  This is where cross-functional teams come into place.

IT is accustomed to interfacing with employees and not automation.  While humans are not reliable, they can adapt to new interfaces and processes by intuition.  Automation is the opposite way around.  Industrial automation is rigid and has its own interfaces.  It's almost always easier to adapt to it than the other way around.

With respect to business processes, there is a lack of accountability.  Successful implementations typical have some sort of departmental liaisons or business process owners.  This is especially useful for solving "garbage in, garbage out" problems.  Users can use and abuse.  Owners are invested in maintaining.

OT has made too narrow of assumptions of all the different consumers, directly or indirectly, of the data they generate.  Ruthless adherence to getting product out the door under any circumstance can create tribal knowledge or discontinuities from the rest of the org.  If this is not fed back and formalized at some point, its mere improvisation.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think SaaS has made the best-of-breed strategy much more feasible than it has been in the past.  The modern architecture, having the ecosystem on the same code base, and limits on the customization has made integration much easier.  It's far less of a risky science project.

At the same time, there are some continuities in functionality or business processes that can't really be broken up.  There are these natural limits of what can be swapped out and where to integrate.  "Good enough" can easily beat out trying to resolve dichotomies.  Short of creating and maintaining interfaces that completely hide the complexity, there is a non-trivial cost of creating the awareness of what an integration can or cannot do.  It can be hell for users jumping between systems.  The unknowns and corner cases can wreak havoc.  As much as we'd like, we still don't live in a world of seamless micro-services that can be interchanged.  Everything, especially in the industrial space, is much more tightly coupled and more difficult to abstract than we imagine.

I have a major customer that issues their supply chain PO numbers with a placeholder (e.g., 111111) when they create a BOM out of sequence.  This is caused by poor integration between PLM and MP&L applications.  It causes all sorts of problems with their receiving and A/P processes.  What one gains in one area they can just as easily lose out in another.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I thought Jon's question was interesting and was looking forward to the responses.  While I don't think it's malicious for not mentioning vendors, I don't believe it benefits the community.  

One of the greatest challenges for consumers in this space is that they are not privy to the "inside baseball" of the market.  There are very high-levels of mystification, both intentional and unintentional, in the ERP and MES space.  It takes deep experience to sort through it.  Even seasoned professionals require considerable time to vet a solution.

If a vendor would like to defend their solution, there is nothing stopping them from chiming in.  I don't believe anyone should be scrutinized for disclosing a solution they have seen works well in the real world.  If a partner does not believe this, they probably should not be a partner.  Ultimately, transparency benefits everyone.  For vendors, they know where their product falls short and they can improve.  For manufacturers, they can make informed decisions and mitigate risk of project failure.  This even reduces uncertainty and cost in the sales cycle.

If you're not comfortable, I totally understand.  There are certainly valid reasons.  But, being able to hear someone say "I have observed X work well for Y, but not Z" unfiltered is invaluable.  An opinion should not necessarily be constructed as a formal endorsement or recommendation.  If anything, it encourages others to independently discover if they share the opinion.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Now we are talking. I can see so many problems with the stack you are referencing here. Not sure how much experience you have in integrating enterprise systems, but this is what I have done my whole life (over 20 years and I have seen all good, bad, and ugly). What you are proposing here is a recipe for disaster. How do I know this? Well, my role in most of the accounts is to kick out siloed systems and create a consolidation strategy, so they can grow. Well, I don't know a business leader who is even remotely comfortable with such deep data mapping as that requires a much deeper experience of messages and transactions. So, these companies end up hiring a consulting company like us. Also, in all honesty, this is the kind of project and the client we want to find. Why? Because it's a million-dollar client that will be locked with us for the lifetime as we will technically have subject-matter expertise on the integration code. Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
I would start with why you need to manage the inventory. I don't think it's clear in your note. A WMS solution is typically involved, even the smaller ones when you have a need for the barcoding. But since you are going to carry low amounts of inventory, you might not need barcoding. I have never seen machine builders using barcoding for their machine division, even for the mid to large-sized shops. Now in terms of managing your inventory, here are some areas you might want to look at in terms of feature set:

1. Where are your major pain points in maintaining inventory? Do you maintain separate inventory for the finished machines and spare parts? What's the revenue/inventory share there? Do you use inventory on service/maintenance orders? Do you need to manage the inventory there?
2. Is the motive for this acquisition financial or operational? How happy are you with your inventory levels right now? Is your physical and digital inventory in sync? Can you plan your inventory when you need it and where you need it? How are your BOMs structured? Do you use projects instead of BOMs for your custom machine build? Do you have any BOMs inside your projects?
3. How is your procurement structured? Do you need to plan your inventory the way you buy from your vendors?

A lot of people in this community are going to hate me for this but I am a big proponent of not digitizing the processes unless you have a clear sense of where you are losing the money and why you are losing it. Until that point, the simplest solution is always manual and spreadsheets.

As per the suggestions from others, QuickBooks Commerce is slightly more trade-centric, so not sure how it will work in your case, especially if you might be using a lot of point solutions. ODOO inventory may be better suited.

Content:

the financial perspective would be cost savings due to overarching planning of inventory, better restructuring of inventory to utilize cost savings, and better aligning sales, ops, and procurement processes as they interact with inventory to utilize cost savings due to volume discounts, etc.

the operational perspective would be, hey I needed 4 parts here or by this date to complete my machine, but now I am stuck as I thought I had 4 parts, but turns out I can't find the fourth one. You may not be able to find it as your inventory is managed like a pile of junk or the disconnect between digital and physical inventory. Love the third motivation being regulatory, and yes it requires far more planning before you start losing money because of failed compliance or increased admin overhead in compiling reports each time you need to submit to your authorities.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Keeping more inventory is the exact opposite of what a savvy finance/ops/inventory professional would tell you. There is a very high correlation between how well inventory is managed and how quickly you can grow. The more cash you have locked up in your inventory, the less it is available to run your business. 

But this effective management is not possible unless all of your processes are tightly integrated, which is what an ERP system typically provides. 

If you are going to use several fragmented systems, it's very hard to get that centralized view of the inventory, which is critical for planning, scaling, and growth. 

But yeah, if you keep a managed and predictable buffer and you don't have any other ways of solving this problem, then keeping a bunch of extra nuts and bolts that cost a fraction of cents wouldn't hurt. 

Also, it would be advisable to keep critical components in the buffer as the costs of disruption may be way higher than the part itself. 

But if you try to keep 20% extra inventory, just to cover "just in case" scenarios, you are already screwed.

Content:
People have elected to homebrew ERPs before.  It can work if an org is truly competent and committed to managing the solution.  Most internal apps don't get lifecycled like they should.  I tend to believe that most EPR functions are not truly differentiating.  For this reason, I'm more inclined to recommend adopting an off-the-shelf solution and extending it with customizations/integrations where needed.

I'd advise partnering up with an ERP consulting firm or perhaps even a very cooperative and knowledgeable customer.  The only way to really get acquainted is through experience.  While it's not say that "rolling your own" ERP is bad experience, it's probably not the right experience to help manufacturers.  For example, your customers may use an ERP for manufacturing business processes and your firm may use it primarily for services and distribution.  The kinds of problems and solutions will be so different.  The other issue is scale.  What works for a small business is dramatically different than what works for medium or large business.

It seems like Odoo and some integrations might be appropriate for your org.  I would even kick the tires on commercial solutions.  Don't write off your business and its headcount as too small for many solutions.  Some orgs, especially today, are super efficient and may have high output (e.g., revenue, volume, projects) per employee.  Or, you might be growing.  I've seen orgs that spend as high as 16% of their revenue on ERP at launch of a period of planned growth.

To sum it up, I'd advise to do what makes sense for your business and separately obtain knowledge of the solutions your customers use.

Content:
In lay terms, the major difference between iPaaS and BPM would be that iPaaS only caters to technical systems whereas BPM is designed for human-centric workflows along with systems. In this case, system 1 may call system 2 and before calling system 3, it might need to wait for a user to complete an action before system 3 can be called. 

iPaaS would not be suitable for such workflow. You need a BPM. These interactions are far more common in the industries such as banking, insurance, telecom, and real estate, with so many front-line workers interacting/touching the loan app etc. So they are the right candidate for BPM tools.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think of BPM in two ways which I'll present down below.  In either case, BPM is like another appliance or utensil in a kitchen.  It's there to solve specific problems.

**BPM as Service**
BPM can be another term for outsourcing or managed services.  Companies like Avalara or ADP are good examples.  Let‚Äôs use payroll as an example.  A lot of ERP/HCM suites may have Time & Attendance, Time Off, or even some Payroll functionality.  But, there is often a services component to payroll such as tax and compliance.  This is a unique business process that varies over time and across localities.  As a result, it's often paired with software and services from a third-party payroll provider.  It can be optimal to decouple this from other systems of record.

**BPM as Workflow**
BPM can also be catch-all phrase for workflow engines.  Legacy applications often required extensive customization to accommodate business processes that were not natively supported.  This was costly to lifecycle and make changes to.  As a result, BPM suites became prevalent to complement other applications.  BPMs reduce the engineering effort in managing business processes.  

The next generation applications have much more configuration and integration capabilities embedded within.  These platform capabilities are thought of as a core product and other applications are designed to interface with them.  Workday‚Äôs ‚ÄòBusiness Process Framework‚Äô is a good example of this.

For the industrial automation folks, this is like the difference between a legacy SCADA such as RSView/FTView vs Ignition.  One was designed for specific purposes while the other was designed for the same thing, but with a platform that can be applied to unspecified purposes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
-
**BPM in Digital Transformation**
Next-generation applications, with embedded workflow engines and platform capabilities, should hopefully reduce the need for traditional BPM.  The era of building out on-prem, point-to-point integrations between specific versions of software is over.  Where I do see BPM having new life is with products such as ServiceNow or even IIoT platforms such as Ignition.  Simply put, these solutions allow users to solve problems without the challenges of the past.  They can be applied and extended to countless business processes.  ServiceNow is particularly interesting because it‚Äôs a version-less SaaS with tons of maintained integrations.  Additionally, it has all the integration capabilities to interface with an organization‚Äôs own IIoT ecosystem.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
I am personally not a big fan of calling any system rigid. The rigidity is subject to how tight your data structure needs to be and how much control you need with your processes. Compare this with NotePad and Excel, which is more rigid and better? Notepad might be easier as you can write anything you like. Excel might be slightly more rigid for you as it might throw errors here and there when you try to enter data. Each tool is designed for a specific purpose and they all have a role to play in architecture depending upon how much money you have in your pockets and how much you hate your life. The challenge is going to be in making them work together.

Now to your question, while you can hook up your PLC with ERP. Ideally, ERP must not contain any of the operational data that is used at the plant level. When I say operational data, I don't mean part number, qty, etc. Since this information is likely to be used by multiple systems, you need to keep it centralized. And that drives what needs to be in an ERP and what doesn't. The operational data such as temp, pressure, how heat valves are performing, it is too much information for ERP. So it must reside in the operational system like MES. Just like if you had imagery for your eComm system, ERP is a terrible place to store them, unless they need to be used by multiple teams as instructions on a BOM. So why do you need an MES system? Because your operational needs to be deeper than what ERP or manual processes can provide.

Content:
Yes I am a big fan of iPaaS for the following reasons: 1) in-built infra and debugging layer at each step of the process 2) ability to throttle load across systems with different enterprise integration patterns 3) much more control in scaling 4) visibility into data and processes as the information travels through different stages 5) architectural clarity and Hygiene. 6) ability to incorporate disparate technologies and systems in your architecture. 7) superior failover with queuing and reconciliation etc.  That said, not all iPaaS are created equal. And they are definitely not supposed to be doing everything. They have a role to play. 

I have seen iPaaS being killed with overengineering. In one engagement, they literally try to write the whole application inside iPaaS. And the application was as thick as processing invoices for Walmart. Trust me, just one customer and invoice has the potential to kill all of your systems and architecture if you don't know what you are doing. And then goes $20-30 million, down the drain. üòÜ  Been there, done that.

Author: geoffnunan
Content:
It's a great question @sasi, and in some very simple scenarios you certainly can connect PLC directly to ERP. I've seen that done in very simple processes like mining, where the basic process description can be stated as "Dig up earth, put earth on train" and Production orders last for 1 month, and only 1 product is made (Earth).
In many manufacturing verticals, the process is infinitely more complex, and there is a big divergence between the level of detail that is required to control the process in the PLC, and the level of detail that the ERP cares about, so there is then a mapping that is required between those levels of detail.
Of course, it's possible to build an MES into your PLC code. An MES is really a conceptual grouping of a set of functions focussed around the execution of a production schedule. I've certainly built PLC code in the past that had all the functions of an MES, but it was not something that could ever be moved to a different production line, or copied into another factory.

So my take on the answer to your question is:
 - in some very simple processes, there is no real difference between the level of detail that the ERP is looking for, and the level of detail required to control the process, and in these processes there can be limited need for MES functions.
- in all other processes, there is a need to manage MES activities ( Check ISA95 Part 3 for what is meant by MES activities)
- MES activities can be handled in PLC code, ERP code or something in the middle like an MES system. Separating the system that performs MES activities  from ERP and PLC allows it to be more easily deployed across an organisation.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Agreed.  The marketing and hype of Marketo far exceeds the reality.

Great points on iPaaS vs. custom.

Most of the Plex integrations have been historically custom.  A lot of these date back (and built upon) the legacy SOAP web services that were stood up before cloud and multi-tenancy was really a thing.  Middleware was very on-prem orientated back then.  Boomi is the unofficially favored iPaaS.  It shows up in more complex integrations involving two-tier ERP and financial consolidation (e.g., Workday, SAP, Hyperion, OneStream).  Some of the partners offer maintained integrations for easily marketable things like payroll.  For machine integration, the partners are typically leveraging SCADA platforms like Tridium Niagara or Ignition.

Because there is so much burden on the customer, I've seen scenarios where Boomi was eventually ditched for custom.  I think iPaaS works out well when the connections are "maintained" in sufficient numbers by the vendor and/or community.  This creates a marketplace-of-sorts for certainty and reliability in integration projects.  It's far easier to be patient "n+1" than patient 0.  But, when one is merely leveraging a generic HTTP interface and they're solely responsible for everything, the licensing costs can outweigh the benefits over time.  As firms become better at managing integrations and keeping their scale/scope stable, it can be economical to go custom.  But, they must be prepared to commit to life cycling it.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
They inked an agreement a few years ago. It has not made a huge difference IMO. It's not as substantive as IFS.

Boomi has been around informally for a while. I think the vision was to make "two-tier" ERP more seamless to sell the MES and operationally-focused ERP modules up-market. They know they weren't going to displace ERP at conglomerates or larger firms, but they could potentially at the operational business units running disparate or legacy solutions. Unfortunately, I think there was so much variation and complexity in these up-market implementations that it probably wasn't worth the cost of inking a formal deal. The vision was to make Workday and Boomi official partners, but I think they chickened out once they saw the cost. Also, various acquisition interests over the years likely complicated matters further.  And there's also the endless "UX" interface project they've been working on for nearly a decade.

Boomi became an unofficially favored solution for implementations among customers and partners because they already began to go down that path. It was easier to build upon the work that was already done. Because it wasn't an official partnership or offering (aka "supported"), customers still owned most of the risk. Once one knows what they're integrating and has the talent to do so, ditching Boomi could be economical. Unless a customer has a comprehensive use of iPaaS, the benefits can be limited if the vendor support isn't there -- particularly if the integration is well scoped/scaled.

Plex's legacy APIs are basically stored procedures / data sources exposed through a SOAP interfaces. The newer APIs are HTTP (what some might call REST).  Some expose the same data sources, but others are more intent-based and sophisticated. These are less convoluted and "kill more birds with less stones" than the legacy ones.  Some have been marketed as specific connectors for more popular integrations (e.g., SPC Checksheet Data, Machine Integration, Payroll, Sales Tax).

Content:
Hi all, I have read several peer reviewed academic journals around the topic of Total Cost of Ownership, Return on Investment, and the effect that ERP software and ERP vendors have on manufacturing companies. 

By and large, every bit of literature points to the massive failure of ERP software to live up to its grandiose promises of ‚Äúbetter integration‚Äù and ‚Äúturning a profit to the customer‚Äù. I simply do not understand how proprietary ERP software could have ever accomplished these proposed goals, let alone now in an ever connected ecosystem.  My viewpoint also comes as an ERP integrator. 

I‚Äôd love to hear other folks‚Äô thoughts on ERP software. Basically, what I am saying is proprietary ERP software is a sham and was relentless marketed towards executive decision makers with the false premise of ‚Äúintegrating the company‚Äù and has miserably failed to live up to any of its promises in the 30 years it has been around. A much better alternative would be SaaS financial applications that use open standards. 

Thanks.

Content: I don't agree - I think integration at some level is essential due to the master data problem(s). As companies became more global, the complexities of cross-border and multi-currency accounting grew by orders of magnitude.  Thus the SAP's of the world.  Plus, SAP, having started in Germany with a HUGE manufacturing customer base, had to implement manufacturing-specific functionality from relatively early days.  I have my biases because I like SAP as a company, yet even SAP is now effectively a "best of breed" vendor through its many acquisitions.

Author: enrimarini
Content: I have nothing against any particular vendor because they all are guilty of using tactics like account control to shill software to their customer base that ERP vendors have no expertise or mature products in. The early days of ERP (and still to this day, although to a lesser extent) were a massive gold rush/cash grab. Ultimately, it is still the widely accepted belief that "best of breed" ERP software is essential and that it is a critical part of staying alive. What ERP vendors should have done from the beginning was to simply work on creating open international API standards to communicate with financial transaction processing software. Let's not fool ourselves, ERP software from any vendor is incredibly basic in functionality because  it is nothing more than a transaction processing tool.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
There are many considerations depending on how you would like to design your architecture.

1. The ERP needs at least contextual information to be able to control inventory, costing, and scheduling. Some people might argue that scheduling belongs to the MES or shop floor systems. But you need to define a clear boundary of who is responsible for what. And what data exchange needs to happen in both systems to facilitate this collaboration. 
2. Inventory and master data are where all the problems start with best-of-breed systems. So as long as you have a clear state of the inventory and product data and how that will be used by the downstream systems such as the shop floor is critical for the success of the architecture. It doesn't matter which path you take, whether you would like to go for best-of-breed or integrated, as long as you have a clear understanding of the roles and responsibilities of each system and how they will be collaborating on the shared data. Obviously, if you are buying integrated systems such as ERP, it will always be less expensive once you account for all the costs. The more integration points, the higher chances of failure, and the more expensive it gets. 
3. The biggest challenge is always the organizational alignment and politics within the organizations. And how every department feels that they are better than the others whether you talk about shop floor or sales or marketing. The successful digital transformation requires a clear state of each system and what role they will be playing in the architecture. Unfortunately, these issues are rarely technical as politics get in the way with departmental conflicts and siloed mindset.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
A lot of folks might disagree with me on this forum. But as far as my understanding goes, the intent of UNS architecture is not to extend the operational boundaries. The fundamentals of UNS architecture are not new. It has been used inside apps and in business apps, for many decades. The same concepts are being utilized to implement the industry4.0 architecture in the form of UNS. 

But note that, you might feel that the world of operations or Industry4.0 is going to take over the world or over the enterprise IT. But unfortunately, every single department feels the same way, whether you talk about sales, procurement, or HR. That's how complex the enterprise architecture has become. I see UNS as the collaborator for operational apps. I really don't think it will replace the existing integration tool in the architecture. In fact, the UNS might feed the context to the existing integration tools. 

By the way, not many people understand that even the world of integration is very complex, and not every tool is a fit for every use case. They are typically used for a specific use case. And UNS would be a fit for very specific operational integration scenarios and not meant to be a replacement for existing tools or integration tech.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Again, these decisions can't be binary. The best-of-breed approach has merits. In fact, I talk a lot about NOT shoehorning everything inside an ERP. But that advice is not meant to be binary. The intent of this advice is to evaluate each case and see what makes sense. In general, the fewer data stores you have in your architecture, the easier it is to integrate and manage. The more databases, the more variabilities, and the more reconciliation points. And a surefire way to fail!

If I recall correctly, they were championing Zuora as the best-of-breed application for subscription billing. Until they failed! And by that time, these capabilities became equally comparable in NetSuite or other ERP systems. So they started advising against Zuora. Also, they started advising against Workday, which is supposed to be one of the most powerful HCM systems out there. If best-of-breed architecture is so easy to pull off, why would they advise against Workday?

There are many variables to assess the fit for a best-of-breed architecture. What is the intent of the system? Is it an analytical system? Or a transactional system? Does it have its own data store? If so, does it touch the master data? If it touches master data, does it simply use or change the state of master data? If it changes, does it augment or replace? These are just the 30K foot level questions you need to be asking. But evaluating these decisions requires very deep expertise in enterprise architecture. And not a checklist approach. If you have never done this before, it is in your best interest to get something pre-integrated. Then worrying about the integration mess. And that's probably the reason why ERP systems exist, to begin with. üôÇ

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
The term best-of-breed is used to refer to an application that is specialized for departmental use than using an integrated app such as ERP.  Best-of-breed apps have their merits as they reduce training time. If you have hourly workers, it might be harder for them to navigate on ERP screens. So you kind of reduce their workflow and simplify the apps. So that ops can progress with their transactions faster. And then finance can reconcile it later. But in this scenario, you are simply delaying the problems. That might be OK for some businesses. But again, you need to assess the ROI to understand what's superior for your specific operations.

Typically if the purpose of integration is just to analyze the data, no one cares as long as you are not killing the system with a massive workload. And if you are moving data for analytical purposes, you can do whatever you want and use as many best-of-breed apps as you like. The problem is when the analytical layer starts to hijack the operational workflow. That's not a good place to be.

In general, there are three ways of integrating any enterprise apps and they all have their pros and cons 1) UI-driven integration (really fragile and not to be taken seriously üôÇ ) 2) service-layer integration 3) database-layer integration. The holy grail of integration will always be to integrate at the DB layer level, the way MS approaches their integration. But that is not always possible if you are a company that grew through acquisition. Because the underlying data model and tech are going to be so different. And that's why most companies attempt service-layer integration, which is also commonly referred to as API-driven integration. This is exactly what companies like Aptean, Infor, and Epicor are attempting to do.

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
Apologies if I am off but in general, I call a thinking "binary" when the advice comes across as "this is the only way to do it." In your case, you seem to have paraphrased that best-of-breed architecture has merits because of cost and advancement in technologies. Yes, that is true, but that is not to say that best-of-breed will always be cheaper, even today. 

In fact, you have far higher chances of failing with best-of-breed than with an integrated app. Because with integrated apps, the same codebase has been tested and used by many corporations. So you kind of know that it works. With best-of-breed, a ton of code needs to be written and tested from scratch. 

This is similar to manufacturing. Which approach is smarter? Creating every single part from scratch or buying off-the-shelf? Seasoned manufacturers will advise reducing the number of variables as much as possible. And if you have access to off-the-shelf components that can be assembled, that is likely to give you less headache than creating everything from scratch. Because reinventing the wheel is rarely wise and smart!

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
On paper, the service layer integration looks easy. How hard could mapping the APIs be? This is exactly how companies such as Infor, Epicor, and Aptean started. A bunch of smart finance folks got together in a room and said you know what SAP is not as smart as they think they are. We are going to buy every best-of-breed app in the market and integrate using the service layer (APIs). In theory, it should work, right? But, unfortunately, in reality, it's much harder to integrate using the service layer. And that's why you will hear a lot more integration issues with the company that grew through acquisitions. Whether you talk about NetSuite integration with its WMS, LogFire integration with Fusion, Infor OS, Epicor, or Aptean.

So when you hear Eric say that even the ERP vendors might run into integration challenges with their own products, he is typically referring to these issues. But the solution is not to write the integration from scratch for every single scenario.

Author: walker.reynolds
Content: This is the hardest conversation -- ERP.  Rather than treating ERP as a node, we generally break ERP into its separate functions and create the function as a node (Work Orders, BOM, Schedule etc) with their own namespaces.  We integrate Odoo natively into UNS via MQTT but still use some of the REST calls with the IIoT Platform.  The place where most people, new to UNS architecture, struggle is with transactions.  The best example would be something like license tags in SAP, where we are sending confirmations that steps have been completed.  Most engineers are used to engineering produce/consume with a 1 to 1 relationship between confirmation and consumer via a message queue, FIFO.  It is generally hard for someone to change the way they think about handling these transactions -- we treat them as mission critical events with high qos, retention and s&f -- but only after confirming the events are being sent in the correct order.  This requires additional work but its necessary.  Sometimes it means transaction history in SQL on both ends being reconciled, sometimes its just a coded watch dog.  This is where architects come in.  But -- at the end of it all you have a single source of truth that is edge driven, report by exception lightweight and open... oh... and available to future consumers with little to no integration.

Author: akoscs
Content:
It is also a point of view question. Even a microservices application equals a monolith from your perspective if you only have one central API to interact with it. But also...you do not really care much if an application is monolith or not if you do not operate and maintain it AND you do not have access to the inner workings of a platform. I mean you can use the best microservice SaaS in the world but if you have one API ingress point (even it it exceptionally well load balanced) and you do not have access to the inner message bus and services, it does not make any difference if it is a monolith or not from your perspective (given that it runs well). It all comes down to the quality of that API. You care even less if you only use its UI.

So.. to answer your question, as long as you do not have well documented access to the inner workings of the ERP, you do not have much advantage if you have a microservices approach or a monolith or anything in-between. Home grown ERP should be microservices based, or you should start to break up your legacy monolith if you have one. MS dynamics (I guess that is what you meant by Business Central) in the background is probably not a monolith, but I doubt it is a microservices architecture. My bet is on SOA. (for me SOA is inbetween microservices and monoliths, where the services are larger, i.e. not micro).

Author: samguptawbsrocks
Content:
The challenge with these use cases is that there is a very thin line between what should be kept inside the ERP vs outside. Unfortunately, for manufacturing and inventory, the processes are so tightly integrated that if you kept everything outside, you will still struggle. Also, the more you keep it outside, the more expensive it gets with the integration challenges, etc. 

The easiest  way to think about this would be whether the data is used across departments or just one department. If it is cross-functional data set like customer, vendor, or inventory, then it has to go inside the ERP. Otherwise, the functional apps can keep, augment as they like, as long as they are not augmenting something that needs to be used by other departments. 

You might also end up storing some data that is purely used as a transport. For example, say  the Amazon channel requires a tracking number and the tracking number is produced by the TMS, so you might need to store the tracking number inside the ERP. Or the ERP might be completely bypassed. It might be OK to bypass ERP in certain instances if the dataset or use case is not operational or financial in nature. But in general, you need to probe a lot before making these decisions. That's why the  architecture is super critical. These decisions are not meant to be binary.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
To create a clear and efficient solution, separate concerns instead of rigging a specific report. This may initially appear complex, but it simplifies the process and aligns with Microsoft's intended use of the platform. Store all inputs (who, what, where, when) in a table for aggregation and summarization. Establish separate related tables for common filterable objects and dimensions. Integrate these values into a common database, functioning as a data warehouse, ensuring consistent naming across sourced systems.

Assuming you have purchased Power platform resources, you can utilize Power Automate with Power BI Paginated reports (formerly SSRS) for emailing and generating PDFs on timed subscriptions. By separating concerns, you can create a Power BI analytical resource and paginated reports simultaneously, with results achievable in less than a week.

While there are concerns regarding Power Apps, Microsoft has made significant improvements. Simplify their use by delegating data transformations to an ETL or ELT process for a data warehouse. Limit user inputs to field validation and store data for downstream transformations. The Power Query and Power BI environment are designed for this analysis and reporting stage.

Power BI Paginated Reports/SSRS and Power BI serve distinct purposes and should be used interchangeably based on the best fit. Power BI has a component that integrates SSRS-style reports, which is useful for fixed formats with strict space usage, such as daily performance reports, production orders, or master recipes.

Power BI excels in flexibility and data exploration for establishing KPIs. When SSRS became Power BI Paginated Reports, the main change was the ability to use Power BI models as a source instead of SQL.

In your case, emailing a fixed-format report is ideal. Creating a model that acts as a KPI originator, filterable by all dimensions in the model with a single definition, provides a strong incentive to use a Power BI model as a source for SSRS-style Power BI reports over SQL.

Author: douga.7429
Content:
By initially creating a database using SQL, we can leverage the advantages of SQL as a more mature and optimized platform. Some of the most compelling reasons to use SQL include:

Advanced querying capabilities that enable complex filtering, aggregation, sorting, and joining multiple tables based on different conditions.

Better performance when working with large datasets or complex operations, as SQL is designed for efficient database management.

Seamless integration with various data platforms, programming languages, and tools, making it widely supported across technologies.

The ability to create stored procedures, user-defined functions, and triggers for better code organization, reusability, and automation.

Support for transactions and concurrency control to ensure data consistency and integrity in multi-user environments.

After establishing the database using SQL, we can then utilize Power Query in Power BI for the final data transformations, such as pivoting. In certain scenarios, Power Query's M language might have advantages over SQL, especially when dealing with unique or complex data transformation requirements. Power Query's user-friendly interface and its integration with the Power BI suite make it a valuable tool for handling specific data manipulation tasks that may not be as straightforward in SQL.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
IQMS is an manufacturing-centric ERP with MES modules.  Tulip is a "frontline operations platform".  Tulip would typically be deployed alongside or, depending on the use case, in place of an MES.

IQMS was acquired by Dassault Systemes a few years ago. It's now called DELMIAWorks.  It's targets mid-market manufacturing where there is often a desire for consolidated solutions with less complex implementations.  There are obvious pros and cons to this.  I believe one noteworthy mention of IQMS is its quality management functionality.  Out-of-box, it's surprisingly strong in discrete and batch.  It's viewed as one of the more positive solutions in terms of getting through an audit.  I've seen some organizations migrate to other ERPs for other reasons but still leverage IQMS for quality workloads and compliance.

The solution overlap between Tulip and IQMS are small.  IQMS is a broad suite to address, at varying levels of efficacy, most functional departments (office and plant) in a manufacturing org.  Tulip is flexible tool to solve human-centric manufacturing problems.  For example, if a particular screen in IQMS was not well-suited to a particular production process or was cumbersome to use by operators, one could use Tulip as an alternative.  But, Tulip is not going to be a 1:1 substitute for an MES and definitely not for an ERP.  The target buyers for each solution are different.  They're either solving different problems or solving them very differently.

I suppose it comes down to what is the desired outcome.  Do you need a manufacturing ERP (e.g., financials, warehousing, scheduling, MES, QMS, CMMS)?  Or, do you need flexible manufacturing apps for frontline employees without the rigidity/limitations of an MES or ERP?  Or, do you need integration strategy?  Or, do you need all of these things?

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Building on Rick's response, having explict interface to return changes or push them out unsolicited is ideal.  It's rare with most transactional systems.  They're not event-driven.  Everything is very database-centric.  

There are some things in the ERP that are the result of human-driven transactions (e.g., creating new parts, creating new customers) and some that are automated (e.g., EDI-driven releases, requirements planning / scheduling creating Work Orders or Kanban cards).  They don't necessary need to all be continuously polled for changes.  One approach is to cache the results and refresh them on some interval based on when they might be updated.  Another approach is to update semi-frequently by default, but add additional triggers such as when a changeover event for special cases and create some limits on requests (e.g., assume no more than x changes in y time period).  It also helps if there is an endpoint that returns a snapshot of all open work orders, active workcenters, etc.  This helps aggregate the requests rather than having hundreds or thousands of assets beat up an endpoint every time they need to retrieve data.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Basically, yeah.  It's not an exciting answer involving exciting technology and new possibilities.  It's a mature space with well-defined industry conventions.  Some major OEMs design their supply chains around this tech.  If one is a smaller player this these supply chains, they don't really have a choice in the technology they use.  Their customer or industry may require them to.  ERPs are long lifecycle technology with a lot of inertia.  It's hard to deviate where the benefits exceed the costs.  There are existing investments in integrating EDI with ERPs.  All those documents have have been mapped to APIs or database procedures.

EDI, along with some of the domain-specific XML standards for finance and procurement (e.g., cXML), will make up the bulk of supply chain integration.  I know people have occasionally discussed company-to-company UNS here, but I would not say that's a major trend.  That's a custom approach implemented that requires alignment and specific technology know-how.  It's probably more likely to be adopted if there isn't an existing infrastructure for conducting commerce or the infrastructure does not work well for the use case.

EDI is a mature technology where it's day-to-day operation and basic support can be overseen by non-technologists (e.g., supply chain, logistics, schedulers, accounting analysts).  Even though it's primitive text files, there exist many document specs to exchange all sorts of things beyond scheduling, ordering management and shipping/receiving.  Traceability, certificate of analysis, inventory, and treasury functions come to mind.  It can do more than what most realize or their ERP supports.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
While EDI as document specs are not evolving much, the way EDI is traded has.  As companies have been migrating to ERP in the cloud, there's less of a reliance on direct connections.  When an ERP is multi-tenant or it's deployment spans multiple data centers, it can be inefficient or even impossible to use direct connections.  VANs, previously seen as a way to outsource EDI for companies too small to manage it on their own, are becoming much more relevant as companies upgrade their ERPs.  Instead of hosting EDI platforms and managing secure network connections throughout their supply chain, companies are now relaying everything through VAN services to their trading partners.  All the major VANs basically peer and interconnect with each other now.  One can integrate their ERP with a single VAN and conceivably use it to trade with all their customers and suppliers.  This negates the need ofr direct connections among trading partners.

The other trend is some traditional EDI workloads are now being encapsulated and even mapped over API.  I've seen some VANs offer translation services to certain industry or OEM documents specs.  The ERP will exchange the supply chain data in some canonical XML or JSON format with the VAN.  The VAN will convert it to the specific EDI document (e.g., ContosoLtd X12 856 v4010) and exchange it with the trading partner.  This gets the end-user and ERP vendors out of the document mapping business.

Suppose a cloud ERP has dozens or even hundreds of customers that all have some of the same major customers and suppliers.  Does it really make sense as an industry to spin up many secure connections and implement a document mapping for every unique trading partner?  There are a lot of dupicative efforts with this approach.  There are massive efficiencies by having an ERP vendor build a reusable connection to the VANs of the customers/suppliers.  Like a UNS, it decouples the integration of producers and consumers of data.
