Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think the biggest issue is not what direction or solution, but whether an org wants to sit down and think about its business processes.  It's easy to complain about chaos, but it's much harder to determine where to optimize and commit to optimizing.

Mapping out the hire-to-retire, procure-to-pay, order-to-cash, etc processes on a whiteboard is hard enough.  Sometimes people can't even come to a consensus on what is the current process ("No, actually, I do it this way.").  This is why ERP sucks and is hard to do.  There exist a fair share of problems with the solutions, vendors, consultants, etc.  But, it comes down to that the processes themselves are difficult.  They can, directly or indirectly, involve a lot of people and require a pretty deep understanding of many interdependent business functions.

If you don't like the usual suspects, look elsewhere and perhaps look a little bigger.  The customer may be "punching above their weight" in terms of digital maturity and business processes.  For example, their revenue may look "medium", but their revenue-to-employee and margins may be 5x the norm.  Some orgs buy ERP because they're cheap and it's necessary.  Others buy it more strategically.  They may be more concerned with how certain business processes may impact their ability to grow.  For example, can the current A/P process and team handle 3x more volume?  Or, can we handle all the additional BOMs and SKUs at the same pace if the customer base is doubled?  Beyond this, an org may want to refine existing processes and streamline.  For example, it takes too long to close the books.  Or, operations have no reasonable feedback loop on financial performance.  The indicators of P&L or absorbed overhead arrive too late for it to make a difference.

Clunkiness becomes a factor when the ERP isn't a good fit, poorly implemented/maintained, or the user is over-reliant on limited functionality for some key processes.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think this is just an issue of semantics.

To most manufacturing ERP folks, informally, MRP is the umbrella term for scheduling materials.  Even most tiered supply chains and ISO management systems will explicitly spell out MRP, at a high level, as some sort of process to make sure the right materials are available at the right time.

MRP II is almost more of an old research term that came out of applying "IBM era" tech to operations.  It was discussed but not firmly adopted.  It has about as much meaning to an ERP buyer as "cyber physical system" or "asset administration shell" or "digital twin" do to an IIoT buyer.  

Solutions with MRP II capabilities have been rolled up into module names (e.g., {master, finite, infinite, shift} scheduling, production planning, {production, tooling, supply, workforce, material} requirements planning) or something branded.

Author: rickbullotta
Content: Well, I was alive and kicking when MRP II came around (my actual degree was operations research and industrial engineering) and at the time it actually was a meaningful term, and was a step change in functionality (from materials to a more comprehensive set of resources and capabilities).  The manufacturing modules in most ERPs are more like MRP II.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
D365 is a series of logic, tables, interfaces to conduct business transactions.  They don't necessarily have what's needed to run production or a connected operation that spans industrial automation.

It can maintain a set of records of what widgets were produced, their cost, their inventory, their orders, their shipments, etc.  It's not going to help with optimizing the control of a pump to improve yield.  It's not going to know anything about how to change and offset tools in a particular operation.  It's not going to host and enforce a FMEA / Control Plan during the production process.  It's not going to handle the alarms and events sourced from industrial control systems.  It's probably not capable of managing piece level serialization and traceability through a fast, automated process.

Long story short: there isn't a "home" in the ERP for all the things in the factory as well as the data they produce and consume.

A successful integration to a big application suite like SAP is largely a function of having knowledge of it or involvement of someone who does.  This is not something one will find in an integration product.

The first step is not buy anything.  Console apps, postman, testing, asking questions, reading documentation, learning how your SAP implementation works, etc is the way forward. When you can demonstrate success and understanding working with the APIs, use this knowledge to determine what solutions or approach you want to take for putting an integration into production.  It's less of a technology effort as it is more designing or engineering a business process.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs always a strict control issue, but a resource issue.  Many IT functions, at least in industry, are setup to keep the lights on (e.g., keep excel running for end users) and some long term projects (e.g., lifecycle EoL stuff, integrate acquired business units).

I think another factor is that the access patterns that many external parties desire involve a complicated access control policy that may not be in place.  A lot of security models are ‚Äúall or nothing‚Äù until someone spends time segmenting them into roles - which takes time.  When an IT group is under resourced and it‚Äôs not a priority among their influential stakeholders/constituents, it‚Äôs easier to say no.

I think it‚Äôs important to think about the impact of an OT user submitting a ticket requesting access to something where there exists no incumbent access pattern.  It‚Äôs probably not a standard business process or something that was budgeting/anticipated.  The receiving end of such a request may be more accustomed to troubleshooting something that was already defined.  If they have to define something new, that will require more research and effort.  It can take a lot of time to achieve compliance/security objectives, maintain business continuity, and standup services to empower others.  When IT is viewed as a cost center, it‚Äôs easier than not to orient them around a ‚Äúbest effort‚Äù service level that X% of revenue allows.  This means ‚Äúextra‚Äù projects or requests that were not budgeted/planned/approved don‚Äôt receive the attention they could.

TL;DR:  Sometimes an ‚Äúask‚Äù is more complicated than getting it fulfilled throughsubmitting a ticket or sending an email.  There may be complications or resource constraints behind the scene.  Having conversations and building alliances is probably the way forward.

Mentally I look at the following sorts of components

- **Hub**( this is where the UNS "lives" it is the address for my single source of truth

Content:
I don't think you should be called out. I think you should be applauded. This is a thoughtful approach to architecture. You're asking "why?" in a measured way. Pub/Sub is for 1:N, N:1, and especially N:N patterns. When it's 1:1, questions should be raised whether it's necessary or what are delivery requirements (e.g., state, error handling) between a producer and consumer.

For whatever the reason, to some, their "UNS" is one node bouncing events off a broker. One node publishing and subscribing to itself and no plans to evolve with new producers or consumers. It's not even 1:1 like X:Y, but X:X. It conjures up an image of someone trying to play racquetball against themself and keeping score.

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think part of the confusion is driven by some full-suite ERP solutions have MES modules. To the layman, they use the umbrella term (e.g., "ERP", "SAP") to describe the system that happens to both take sales orders and executes work orders. 

And then there is there is the whole spectrum of factors:
-Unaware of MES functionality in ERP
-Did not purchase/license it
-Did not implement it at all
-Did not implement it well
-Did not maintain/extend it
-A different team without operational oversight (e.g., finance) owns ERP
-In some orgs, operations have a very minimal or informal involvement with software

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
I think a major factor for the confusion on MES and ERP in general is that there are very few people in a manufacturing org that understand (or even get exposure to) all the various business processes (e.g., procure-to-pay, order-to-cash, hire-to-retire, plan-to-produce, production execution, production monitoring, quality, product lifecycle, inventory) and the systems to get work done. It's basically a full career specializing on particular process. It's especially difficult for people that spend most of their time putting out fires at L1/L2 to learn other parts of the business.

Useful questions for becoming fluent with business processes and systems:

How do we...
"...receive orders from customers?"
"...schedule the plants?"
"... process inventory?"
"... hire, pay, and train employees?"
"... turn product designs into a manufacturing process?"
"... get through a certification audit for quality, environment, materials?"
"... place orders and pay our suppliers?"
"... create production records?"
"... receive and ship material?"
"... detect and reject non-conforming product?"
"... contain defective product or perform recalls?"
"... calculate the cost of production?"
"... close and report on a fiscal period?"

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Here's a module map from a full-suite manufacturing ERP. It's interesting to see how different business processes and modules can interact.

Even from an implementation standpoint, it's challenging to go deep in all areas. It's very common for implementation practices to have separate people for accounting, scheduling/inventory, production/quality, reporting, etc.

HighByte users have integrated with many versions and flavors of SAP using different approaches including files, database drivers, web services, as well as through IT middleware or data virtualization platforms. Given the complexity and variety of SAP deployments, it‚Äôs not uncommon for different orgs and teams to be opinionated about the specific approach they take.

S4/HANA is more straight forward to integrate with. Perhaps due to cloud deployment models, S4 tends to see less customization on core modules. It seems like people learned their lesson that too much ‚Äúhot rodding‚Äù in ECC came with tradeoffs for integration and maintenance. It‚Äôs not too much work to expose decent intent-based endpoints over HTTP/JSON. It‚Äôs especially easy if the SAP team is using BTP to manage and curate the endpoints. 

In general, integrating with SAP is not so much a technology challenge as it is a people and process challenge. Connecting is the easy part. Finding someone who understands the underlying business process and can demonstrate the process in the UX and APIs is the hard part. At the end of the day, someone devised a process based on business requirements and elected to implement it with SAP in a certain way. That domain knowledge is important.

Check out this reference project. It includes a connection to the sandbox APIs in SAP‚Äôs training environment. It‚Äôs calling an endpoint one would encounter for obtaining maintenance order data from the SAP Plant Maintenance (PM) module.

https://support.highbyte.com/kb/reference/solutions/advanced-unified-namespaces

Author: bright_hummingbird_31342
Content:
Great point on the transactional vs report by exception patterns. This is something I‚Äôve thought a lot about.

In general, ERP and MES apps are not good at consuming telemetry data. Under the hood, they‚Äôre databases constrained by master data and application logic. Outside of some niche verticals and ecosystems, it‚Äôs rare that one‚Äôs industrial automation is designed around this. It‚Äôs even more rare that the application provider devised the right integration patterns and flexibility to accommodate all the variability and different use cases.

When I hear inquiries whether some app (e.g., ERP, MES, WMS) supports MQTT, Sparkplug, or ‚Äúcommon‚Äù OPC UA, I want to dampen the expectations by asking ‚ÄúShould it? Is this really a good idea?‚Äù

Do we really want a ‚Äúdumb‚Äù telemetry feed that forces an integration pattern? Will this limit the use cases we can accomplish? Does it require tedious configuration to setup and maintain? What is the app provider‚Äôs integration strategy? Is it some module that is ‚Äúcute‚Äù for demos and PoCs but inadequate for actual users in production with real requirements? Is it an area of competancy for the vendor and do they put resources into maintaining it? Does the ecosystem eventually bypass it and elect to build their own solutions to facilitate the transactions they need?

In other words, is it better off to flexibly invoke specific methods like ‚Äúrecord production‚Äù, ‚Äúrecord asset state change‚Äù, ‚Äúmove container‚Äù instead of relaying the value of ‚Äústs_code‚Äù or ‚Äúprt_cnt‚Äù machine tags through a rigid ingestion process in an app?

Author: andybmac
Content: The last 2 projects with SAP I;ve been on the IDOC has been retained and wrapped in a  point to point solution with Mulesoft - IT's decision.  At another client we are "speculating" how we could do it with MQTT, but decided that the size of info coming down in an idoc is probably too much... we did wonder whether dropping the idoc into a data store and publishing a reference on the broker might be a half way house - a pseudo pub/sub then for anyone to reference.  For my client SAP and LIMs always go together and the "problem" has been that with both Syncade MES and Opcenter PH EX MES they have "built in" interface options with BI and SAMS respectively that everyone just goes with the "off the shelf" (cough cough) point to point solution.  The only place I have come across an ERP pub/sub (enterprise bus) was using an Oracle ERP to Syncade and LIMs... but the very next project took it back to a point to point solution as IT couldnt see any value for the extra work.  I guess the size of the order and associated BOM has an impact - if its a single unit operation publishing to a broker/UNS should be eminently possible - a full end to end cell culture process order not so much

Author: youri.regnaud
Content: So as not to be dependent on the timing of an S4 migration, we built a synchronous and asynchronous integration layer using Solution as Kong (API and AI gateway), Solace as broker, SAP CPI for your IT orchestrations and Highbyte for industrial Data Ops. My recommendation would be to build an integration layer independent of your editors (SAP, PLM vendor, ...) and not wait for S4 to do so. A good practice is to use S4 API specifications to build SAP ECC/ERP APIs. In short, decouple, build APIs without projecting onto a single use case, document (AI will thank you) and don't oppose synchronous and asynchronous, treat the 2 in the same way (APi first, design first, discovery, as a product, standardization, ...).
